title: Norris Wright Cuney
text:
Norris Wright Cuney, or simply Wright Cuney, (May 12, 1846March 3, 1898) was an American politician, businessman, <a href="labor%20union">union</a> leader, and advocate for the rights of African-Americans in <a href="Texas">Texas</a>. Following the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>, he became active in <a href="Galveston%2C%20Texas">Galveston</a> politics, serving as an <a href="alderman">alderman</a> and a national <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> delegate. He was appointed as United States Collector of Customs in 1889 in Galveston. Cuney had the highest-ranking appointed position of any African American in the late 19th-century South. He was a member of the <a href="Union%20League">Union League</a> and helped attract black voters to the Republican Party; in the 1890s, more than 100,000 blacks were voting in Texas.
Establishing his own business of <a href="stevedore">stevedore</a>s, he helped to unionize black workers in Galveston, opening jobs for them on the docks. He substantially improved employment and educational opportunities for blacks in the city. He eventually rose to the chairmanship of the <a href="Texas%20Republican%20Party">Texas Republican Party</a> and became a national <a href="committeeman">committeeman</a>.
Cuney is regarded by many as the most important black leader in Texas in the 19th century and one of the most important in the United States. 
Early life and education.
Norris Wright Cuney was born on May 12, 1846, near <a href="Hempstead%2C%20Texas">Hempstead, Texas</a>, in the <a href="Brazos%20River">Brazos River</a> valley. He was the fourth of eight children of Adeline Stuart, a <a href="mixed-race">mixed-race</a> slave of African, European, and Native American ancestry. Among his mixed-race siblings, all of whom were white, were his older brother Joseph, who later became an attorney, and his younger brother Nelson, who became a building and painting contractor. Their father was Adeline's white master, <a href="Colonel">Colonel</a> <a href="Philip%20Cuney">Philip Cuney</a>, a wealthy <a href="Planter%20%28American%20South%29">planter</a> of English ancestry. He had a white "first" family and eventually married a total of three white wives after the earliest ones died in childbirth or from disease. All his mixed-race children were born into slavery. Philip Cuney was a politician and was elected as <a href="Texas%20Senate">state senator</a>.
By 1850 Philip Cuney was one of the largest landowners in the state, with 2,000 acres and 105 slaves, including Stuart and her children. In 1860 he was one of the 50 largest slaveowners in the state. Cuney raised cotton but also had a dairy operation, with several hundred cows, plus beef cattle brought to the marriage by his second wife, Adeline Ware, with whom he had three children before her death before 1850. He married for the third time in 1851. Cuney considered <a href="Houston">Houston</a> his home, where he settled in 1853.
By the principle of "<a href="partus%20sequitur%20ventrem">partus sequitur ventrem</a>", adopted from the model of Virginia colonial slave law, the mixed-race, majority-white Stuart children were all born into slavery, as their mother was a slave. Their father freed his mixed-race children and their mother sometime before the Civil War, starting with the oldest son Joseph in 1853. He sent his sons to <a href="Pittsburgh">Pittsburgh</a>, Pennsylvania to the Wylie Street School for <a href="African%20American">people of color</a> for education. When Norris was freed in 1859, he took his father's surname of Cuney. His father sent him to Pittsburgh for schooling at that time. Jennie Cuney was freed and sent to Europe for her education; she later <a href="passing%20%28racial%20identity%29">passed</a> into white society, consistent with her majority-white ancestry. The <a href="American%20Civil%20War">Civil War</a> interrupted Norris' plans to attend <a href="Oberlin%20College">Oberlin College</a> in Ohio, which was open to students of all races and both genders.
After the outset of the war, Norris Cuney gained work on a <a href="steamship">steamship</a> that traveled on the Ohio and Mississippi rivers between <a href="Cincinnati">Cincinnati</a> and <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a>. Spending a great deal of time in New Orleans, he became friends with influential figures such as <a href="P.%20B.%20S.%20Pinchback">P. B. S. Pinchback</a>, a mixed-race man educated in the North who returned to the South after the war. He was elected as a Republican lieutenant governor of Louisiana and succeeded to the position of the state's first black (or, more accurately, <a href="free%20person%20of%20color">person of color</a>) governor.
At the end of the war, Cuney moved back to Texas and settled in <a href="Galveston">Galveston</a>. He entered postwar society as a literate, educated, mixed-race son of a wealthy and powerful white politician father, which gave him social advantages. His mother and brothers joined him in Galveston, where they lived within a few blocks of each other. Cuney began self-study in law and literature.
After the war, Cuney met George T. Ruby, a representative of the <a href="Bureau%20of%20Refugees%2C%20Freedmen%20and%20Abandoned%20Lands">Freedmen's Bureau</a>, the <a href="United%20States%20government">federal</a> agency responsible for providing aid to former slaves and helping them negotiate a free-labor society. Its headquarters in Texas were in Galveston. Ruby was secretly a director of the <a href="Union%20League">Union League</a>, an organization dedicated to attracting <a href="freedmen">freedmen</a> to the <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican Party</a>. (It was a relatively small organization in Texas at the time, as the <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a> had dominated southern white politics and Texas was a white-majority state). Cuney became increasingly involved with the <a href="Union%20League">Union League</a> and Ruby's ideology. In 1870 there were 3,000 blacks in Galveston, nearly one-quarter of its 13,818 total population recorded in the US Census that year.
Career.
Cuney's career rose with Galveston's growth as a port and progressive city. In 1870 he was appointed first sergeant-at-arms of the <a href="Texas%20Legislature">Texas Legislature</a>. He befriended the Republican governor <a href="Edmund%20J.%20Davis">Edmund J. Davis</a>. He was appointed as a state delegate to the 1872 national <a href="Republican%20convention">Republican convention</a> and served in this role for the next two decades, attending every convention until 1892.
In 1871 Cuney's interest in educational opportunities for blacks led to his appointment as one of the school directors for <a href="Galveston%20County">Galveston County</a>. The biracial Reconstruction-era legislature established a public school system in Texas for the first time, and the state was setting it up. Cuney worked to ensure that tax allocations guaranteed education for black students in the segregated system.
Cuney was appointed head of the Galveston chapter of the Union League in 1871. As George T. Ruby left Texas politics, Cuney gained much of his clout without some of his negative associations. Ruby had been strongly connected to unpopular Reconstruction programs. In 1873 Cuney was appointed secretary of the Republican State Executive Committee. That same year he presided over the Texas convention of black leaders in <a href="Brenham%2C%20Texas">Brenham</a>.
In 1872 Cuney was appointed as the federal inspector of customs for the <a href="Port%20of%20Galveston">Port of Galveston</a> and revenue inspector at <a href="Sabine%20Pass">Sabine Pass</a>. Cuney became a popular figure in the community. As reform efforts in the city were pushed forward by the community's business leaders, including the Galveston Cotton Exchange garnering support for harbor improvements, Cuney was asked to participate.
This was a period of dramatic growth in the South and nationally of black fraternal organizations, part of the political organizing by freedmen. While not active in any church, Cuney joined a <a href="Prince%20Hall%20Lodge">Prince Hall Lodge</a> of the Freemasons, which struggled to be recognized by the predominantly caucasian lodges. He recruited new members and contributed to the growth in the number of black Freemasons in Texas. Black lodges were not recognized by the predominantly caucasian grand lodges until the last decade of the 20th century. In 1875 Cuney was elected the first grand master of the Most Worshipful Grand Lodge, Free and Accepted Ancient York Masons of the State of Texas (known today as the Most Worshipful Prince Hall Grand Lodge of Texas) organized by black Masons.
Cuney entered the race for Galveston mayor in 1875 but lost. He similarly lost bids for the state <a href="Texas%20House%20of%20Representatives">House of Representatives</a> and <a href="Texas%20Senate">Senate</a> in 1876 and 1882, respectively. The latter election was after Reconstruction had officially ended in the South with the withdrawal of federal troops. Finally in 1883 Cuney was elected <a href="alderman">alderman</a> of the twelfth district on the Galveston <a href="City%20Council">City Council</a>.
In 1882 Cuney was appointed to the higher position of special inspector for customs at the port. In 1883 he began a <a href="stevedore">stevedore</a> business, employing 500 black dock workers loading and unloading ships. He later organized the black dockworkers into a labor union known as the "Colored Screwmen's Benevolent Association". At the time white unions controlled the labor market on the docks. Cuney pushed black workers to cross white <a href="picketing%20%28protest%29">picket line</a>s and accept lower wages to increase the black presence on the docks and weaken white bargaining power against them. He recruited additional black dock workers from <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a>. Though inequities remained, the Trades Assembly was gradually forced to re-evaluate its racial policies and grant concessions. In 1889 Cuney was appointed as the US Collector of Customs for the port, the highest-ranking federal appointee position of a black in the late 19th-century South.
In 1886 Cuney was elected as the Texas national <a href="committeeman">committeeman</a> in the Republican Party and became the Texas party chairman, the most powerful position of any African American in the <a href="American%20South">South</a> during that century. Cuney's popularity enabled him to shape the republican Party in Texas; his opponents, white and black, were initially unable to challenge his authority in most matters. His role and his importance became nationally recognized, and his accomplishments were reported by "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>".
Cuney's elevation to the Texas Republican chairmanship aggravated some white Republicans in Texas and nationwide. Since <a href="Emancipation%20proclamation">Emancipation</a>, many whites in the young Republican party had worried about alienating Southern whites if blacks were allowed to gain too much influence in the party. Although initially the power of the black vote was seen favorably by the party leaders, this sentiment gradually changed. At the 1888 Republican convention, a group of conservative whites attempted to have a number of important black leaders expelled, leading Cuney to coin the term "<a href="Lily-White%20Movement">Lily-White Movement</a>" to describe the trend. Cuney maintained control of the party in Texas for a time. The majority of the state's population was white, and most were affiliated with the Democratic Party. Some smaller planters and yeomen farmers joined the Republican Party.
In 1892 Democratic politician <a href="Grover%20Cleveland">Grover Cleveland</a> was elected U.S. President, ending national support for Cuney's efforts. He was unseated in 1896 by a white as chairman of the Texas Republican party.
Personal life.
On July 5, 1871, Cuney had married Adelina Dowdie, a local school teacher. Beautiful with grey eyes, she was also mixed race, the daughter of a mulatto enslaved mother and a white planter father. The couple had two children, Maud and Lloyd Garrison Cuney (the boy was named after prominent <a href="Abolitionism%20in%20the%20United%20States">abolitionist</a> <a href="William%20Lloyd%20Garrison">William Lloyd Garrison</a> of Massachusetts). The parents were both musical: Cuney played the violin and Adelina was a soprano singer. They filled their house with music and art, emphasized education for their children, had them learn <a href="Shakespeare">Shakespeare</a>, and worked to shelter them from the racism of Galveston society. With two of Cuney's brothers and their families nearby, the children and their cousins regularly enjoyed frequent gatherings and events together.
Maud Cuney (later known as <a href="Maud%20Cuney%20Hare">Maud Cuney Hare</a> after her marriage), studied in Boston at the <a href="New%20England%20Conservatory%20of%20Music">New England Conservatory of Music</a>. She settled there, writing a biography of her father, published in 1913, and becoming an accomplished pianist, <a href="musicologist">musicologist</a>, author, and community organizer in the city. It had a relatively large population of blacks, many of them migrants from the South. Lloyd Cuney was also well educated; he became an official in the <a href="Congregational%20church">Congregational Church</a>.
Cuney amassed considerable wealth, attaining an estimated net worth of approximately $150,000 in 1893 ($ in today's dollars), according to "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>.".
Legacy.
Some Texas historians refer to the period of the state between 1884 and 1896 as the "Cuney era". It is noted as a time of significant political gains by blacks in Texas. Cuney's efforts to recruit and register blacks contributed to a total of more than 100,000 blacks voting annually in the state during the 1890s (more than 15% of the black population or 4% of the total). The increased power of unionized black dock workers eventually led to interracial unions in Galveston during the decade from the 1890s to the early 1900s.
By the time of Cuney's death, white conservative Democratic-dominated southern state legislatures were passing new constitutions and laws to <a href="Disfranchisement%20after%20Reconstruction%20era">disenfranchise</a> blacks and poor white voters to expel them from politics and secure their dominance after having lost some offices in the biracial coalitions of Populists-Republicans at the end of the century. From 1890 to 1908, beginning with Mississippi, state legislatures created barriers to voter registration that resulted in dramatic reductions of voter rolls and nearly total exclusion of blacks from the political systems. For instance, Texas instituted required payment of <a href="Poll%20tax%20%28United%20States%29">poll taxes</a> and restricting voting in the Democratic nominating process to <a href="white%20primaries">white primaries</a>. The number of black voters in Texas was sharply reduced from 100,000 in the 1890s to less than 5,000 in 1906. By the 1930s and the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a>, racial strife in the unions, in part encouraged by the employers as well as segregationists, had broken much of the former labor cooperation between blacks and whites.
Cuney's example continued to inspire other black leaders. Following his being removed from the Texas Republican chairmanship, <a href="William%20Madison%20McDonald">William Madison McDonald</a>, a black <a href="Fort%20Worth%2C%20Texas">Fort Worth</a> banker, formed an alliance with multimillionaire <a href="Edward%20Howland%20Robinson%20Green">Edward H. R. Green</a> to lead the party. Blacks were disenfranchised and closed out of politics from 1912 on as the "<a href="Lily%20White%20Movement">Lily White Movement</a>" dominated the Texas Republicans. Passage in the 1960s of federal civil rights laws was needed before Texas blacks fully recovered their ability to exercise their constitutional right to vote.
